description: From Middle English surplus, from Middle French surplus. Compare French surplus.

entries.meaning: Being or constituting a surplus; more than sufficient.
examples: The latest shipment of goods is surplus to our needs.

nouns.description: surplus (countable and uncountable, plural surpluses or surplusses)

entries.meaning: That which remains when use or need is satisfied, or when a limit is reached; excess; overplus.
Specifically, an amount in the public treasury at any time greater than is required for the ordinary purposes of the government.
(law) The remainder of a fund appropriated for a particular purpose.
(law) assets left after liabilities and debts, including capital stock have been deducted.

verbs.description: surplus (third-person singular simple present surpluses or surplusses, present participle surplussing or surplusing, simple past and past participle surplussed or surplused)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To treat as surplus to requirements; to sell off or dismiss from employment, etc.
examples: This employee was engaged to direct asphalt plants and inasmuch as the work for which he had been employed was completed, he was surplused and his return travel was approved  [â€¦]
